Still working to get an example... In fact, I meet this problem when I'm testing my implementation of Deep Q Network. The training will be fine if I just run one DQN on a single GPU (I can repeat the results in the Nature paper for multiple Atari games). However, if I try to run two processes on the same GPU, the divergence problem occurs.

In my implementation, I generate two executors using the same set of QNet parameters, one for getting actions and another for updating the parameters. After one step of update using the updating executor, the action executor will need to generate actions using the updated parameters. I wonder if there are some asynchronous behaviors in the engine that cause the divergence...
@danmalter Can you try again? I think I removed openmp this time.

One thing you want to make sure is always use ndarray to pass around dependencies. If you have a reproducible example, we can have a better guess on what is going on.

Thanks very much!
The code LGTM. @pluskid I would consider the crash as a potential BUG. if you can get a reproducible script say on CIFAR or invariant of CIFAR structure, please send a gist and I will look into it

@tqchen Sure, here is a simple example. On this branch, if you change the line 10 of `symbol_inception-bn-28-small.py` to

```
conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=kernel, stride=stride, pad=pad, attr=mirror_attr)
```

basically, add the force mirroring attr to the convolution layer. Then run `train_cifar10_mirroring.py`, you will get


Are you using one optimizer for both executors? That might be a problem.

You need to have libhdfs to compile with HDFS support. The easiest way is
to get a Hadoop 2.0 binary and search for libhdfs in it.

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Template configuration for compiling mxnet

#

# If you want to change the configuration, please use the following

# steps. Assume you are on the root directory of mxnet. First copy the this

# file so that any local changes will be ignored by git

#

# $ cp make/config.mk .

#

# Next modify the according entries, and then compile by

#

# $ make

#

# or build in parallel with 8 threads

#

# $ make -j8

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------

# choice of compiler

#--------------------

export CC = clang-omp
export CXX = clang-omp++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug

DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add

ADD_LDFLAGS = '-L/usr/local/opt/openblas/lib' '-L/usr/local/cuda/lib'  '-L/usr/local/cudnn/lib'

# the additional compile flags you want to add

ADD_CFLAGS = '-I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include' '-I/usr/local/cuda/include'   '-I/usr/local/cudnn/include'

# per https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/728#issuecomment-160867057

ADD_LDFLAGS += -Xlinker -F/Library/Frameworks -Xlinker -framework -Xlinker CUDA

#---------------------------------------------

# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU

#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile

USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag

# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE

# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda

USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda

# whether use CUDNN R3 library

USE_CUDNN = 0

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language (i.e. Python)

USE_NVRTC = 0

# whether use opencv during compilation

# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use

# imbin iterator

USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization

USE_OPENMP = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use

# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas

USE_BLAS = openblas

# add path to intel library, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path

# to environment variable

USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

#----------------------------

# distributed computing

#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable multi-machine supporting

USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is

# required

USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1

LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then

# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by

# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev

USE_S3 = 0

#----------------------------

# additional operators

#----------------------------

# path to folders containing projects specific operators that you don't want to put in src/operators

EXTRA_OPERATORS =

#----------------------------

# plugins

#----------------------------

# whether to use torch integration. This requires installing torch.

# TORCH_PATH = $(HOME)/torch

# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/torch/torch.mk

If you initialized the input to random numbers, the output will also be random

I split the model by using ctx_group in bind. What I did was I split each convolution layer and gave each of them a ctx context. For example, I want to use two gpus, ("dev0", "dev1"). More specifically, I put half of the filters of each layer on each gpu, which means I defined two new layers with half of the fiters of the original one. Then after these two sublayers, I concatenate them in order to let the next layers use the whole part of the feature maps. I split all the conv layers in this way. The motive of doing this was to split the calculation burden, but I found the reality is not. It seems that the communication cost between two gpus has exceeded the benefit of spliting the calculation. The speed is way slower due to the frequent splitting  and concatenating. Any advice regarding this? @mli @tqchen
PR Created. Please check when you're free
LGTM

close this PR as per @mli 's comment
Currently, the device information comes with ndarray during serialization. What you can do is always copy data to CPU before save them.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1736

@pluskid This fixed the mirror problem. This was caused by the behavior of attributes. When automatic variables are copied, the attributes of conv operator is copied to its childs(used for device placement).

So a variable is marked as mirror, which it should not

You can find examples in python examples.

FYI. I spent many times mxnet.cpp implementing missing features and I ended up just using python interface because mxnet.cpp incomplete. it basically not implemented or partially implementing in progress, missing parameters, not tested and even basic symbol operators are just declared yet not implemented.
Furthermore, Bigger problem is implementing optimizer requires modification of mxnet library itself.
All option you have is just using ccsgd and basic thread synchronization is not guaranteed and bugged somewhere you'll eventually get access violations everywhere.
Works great now :)
@mli I have to say that that's not user friendly :( even simple warning could prevent users from hassle figuring out what's wrong with them.. I think that's why @linkerlin made PR at first place..
@christallire Thak you for this ,but my boss want me to use the c++ version of Mxnet.

You should check if there is a folder named `mxnet` in `mxnet/example/image-classification/`
The python wrapper have updated and Python prefer to call methods in the current folder, so If there is a out of time `mxnet` folder, you may encounter this problem.

as you can see some info in the log is not converted, such as `loss1_conv_weight not found in arg_shape_dic....` , the loss1 and loss2 layers does not generated in the new model, so you see it is small.
the convert_model.py cannot convert all the caffe model to mxnet, you should read the code and change it for your convert.
echo $PYTHONPATH to see whether you have a old version of MXNET installed. remove the path from PYTHONPATH and add new location to PYTHONPATH and try again.
Can you post the full error message to help us to locate the error? Thanks!

Thanks for your reply.

I think the problem here is that in the case of bucketing, the saved symbol does not contain information to create symbols for other buckets. Can you try this:

```
# AFTER loading checkpoint, BEFORE running fit()
model.symbol = None
model.sym_gen = sym_gen # the sym_gen defined in lstm_ptb_bucketing.py
```

Please let us know if this workaround works, and we will try to come up with a better API to handle model loading and saving in bucketing.

@constantineshu The prediction API is not bucketing-aware yet. The main reason is that typically the prediction of models using bucketing (usually RNNs) need specialized behavior. For the ptb case, for example, "predicting" means doing a sequence sampling. Note you do **not** see the input sequence as in the training case. Instead, you just see the first character. You need to do a step-by-step sampling by feeding your prediction to the next step. A sampler example can be found in [lstm.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn/lstm.py)

@tqchen @antinucleon @piiswrong Currently the bucketing API does not work well with model checkpoints. There are two options to handle this
- Option 1: use python pickle to also save the `gen_sym` function. This makes it impossible to load the saved model from a different language binding.
- Option 2: require the user to pass the same `gen_sym` to the function `load_checkpoint`, which will basically ignore the saved JSON file for the symbol.

Any preference / suggestions?
I think we can go with option 2 for now. Since bucketing API is mainly aimed for varying inputs

I think we can do both. Override when gensym is provided

Make sure your dll file and your Python have the same bit-width. If you are
using the binary distribution, then you are using 64-bit dll, you should
use a 64-bit Python, too.
